news.title: Southern Region athletics explodes into action
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
THE 2025 Southern Region Senior Athletics Championships kicked off in Harare this Saturday, bringing together 10 countries for a battle of speed, strength and skill at the University of Zimbabwe main arena.
United by ambition and the dream of qualifying for the 2025 Tokyo World Athletics Championships, Southern Africa’s top athletes are in Harare for regional championships.
With over 25 athletes per country, the University of Zimbabwe main arena was a melting pot of talent this Saturday, as sprinters, jumpers and throwers battled for medals on the opening day and potential scholarship opportunities abroad.
“I’m looking forward to making it to the World Athletics Championships. Just reaching the finals would be a big milestone,
“It wasn’t my best day, but I learned so much from competing at this level. I’m honored to be part of this event,”
“We arrived late from Namibia so I wasn’t at my best today, but I’ll give it my all in the 200m tomorrow. The competition is tough, but the track and officials are world-class,” said the athletes
Deputy Minister of Sport, Arts, Recreation and Culture, Honourable Emelly Jesaya highlighted Zimbabwe’s pride in hosting the event.
“The Government of Zimbabwe is proud to be hosting the Confederation of African Athletics. With ten countries represented, this demonstrates our commitment to sport, regional integration, and showcasing Zimbabwe’s capabilities on the international stage,” she said.

news.title: Sables reflect on world cup qualification
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
THE Zimbabwe men’s senior rugby team, the Sables’ qualification for the 2027 Rugby World Cup has been described as testament to the power of teamwork, commitment and shared dreams, a model all sport codes in the country have been urged to adopt.
After three decades in the wilderness, the World Cup dream for the Sables appeared to be far-fetched.
While, on paper the odds were against the Sables, especially against Namibia in the Rugby Africa Cup final, the motivation in the Sables camp spoke of champions and indeed it took a new generation of sportspersons to take Zimbabwe’s rugby to new heights.
Curious about how Sables turned the tables against Namibia first in 2024 and 2025, the ZBC News crew caught up with the Sables captain, Hilton Mudariki.
“Within our group we did not panic we were never under pressure even when Namibia scored. We just knew that if we tick our boxes we needed to do what we’ve worked on over the past couple of days we would have been fine. Thank goodness it came through at the end,” he said.
The last time Zimbabwe participated at the Rugby World Cup was in 1991 and  Mudariki was not yet born.
“Three decades a lot of us were not born maybe one or two were born then so for us to rewrite the history books is something that we had spoken about as a group. It was part of our goals and we did know that each game was going to be our final in order for your to achieve that goal. So, to be part of that is super special and for us I think that the motivating factor was to create heroes that other Zimbabwean boys can look up to and inspire to be. We haven’t seen a green and white jersey at the world cup in a very long time so we’ve made our little contribution hopefully to inspire a St Johns boy, a PE boy, a Milton boy to want to be a sable when they grow up,” he added.

news.title: Chaminuka suspended without pay as Dynamos struggles continue
news.content:
Story by ZBC staff reporter
Troubled Harare giants, Dynamos, have suspended coach Saul Chaminuka for allegedly breaching the employment code of conduct.

news.title: Zimbabwe eyes gold as development archers shine in Namibia
news.content:
Story by ZBC staff reporter
THE Zimbabwe Archery developmental team has made it into the top three of the World AGA tournament in Namibia, and will fight for a gold medal this Saturday.
It was an action-packed day in Namibia this Friday as the Zimbabwe Archery team sought to overcome stiff competition from several countries in pursuit of a better finish at the World AGA tournament.
Andrew Manning emerged as Zimbabwe’s top archer at the event.

news.title: Mupfurutsa takes PSL Chair role after an election victory
news.content:
Story by ZBC Reporter
ISAIAH Mupfurutsa has been elected Chairperson of the Premier Soccer League following elections held in Harare this Friday.
The Simba Bhora Chairperson, Mupfurutsa, got the mandate to oversee the administration of the top-flight league after being elected ahead of Dumisani Sisale of FC Platinum, Leonard Musariri of Ngezi Platinum Stars, and Manica Diamonds’ Masimba Chihowa.
Highlanders’ Kenneth Mhlophe landed the Vice Chairperson’s post unopposed, while Dynamos’ Moses Maunganidze and Oscah Nduwure of TelOne were elected Emergency Committee members.
